bbmm.functions.cholesky_jax module

bbmm.functions.cholesky_jax.cholesky_jax(mat, max_iter=15)[source]

mat: JAX NumPy array of N x N

bbmm.functions.pivoted_cholesky_jax module

bbmm.functions.pivoted_cholesky_jax.apply_permutation(matrix, left_permutation, right_permutation)[source]

Applies a left and/or right (partial) permutation to a given matrix K.

Parameters:

  • matrix (jax.numpy.ndarray) – The input matrix K.

  • left_permutation (Optional[jax.numpy.ndarray]) – Vector representing the left permutation Pi_left.

  • right_permutation (Optional[jax.numpy.ndarray]) – Vector representing the right permutation Pi_right.

Returns:

jax.numpy.ndarray – The result of the permutation.

bbmm.functions.pivoted_cholesky_jax.pivoted_cholesky_jax(mat, error_tol=0.001, return_pivots=None, max_iter=15)[source]

mat: JAX NumPy array of N x N

bbmm.functions.pivoted_cholesky_numpy module

bbmm.functions.pivoted_cholesky_numpy.apply_permutation_numpy(matrix, left_permutation, right_permutation)[source]
bbmm.functions.pivoted_cholesky_numpy.pivoted_cholesky_numpy(mat, error_tol=0.001, return_pivots=None, max_iter=15)[source]

mat: JAX NumPy array of N x N

refered to this discussion https://github.com/cornellius-gp/gpytorch/discussions/2067 code https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1sLNdLi3sI0JKO9ooOsuS6aKFBDCdN3n8?usp=sharing#scrollTo=KE0CTvRmN-nP

bbmm.functions.pivoted_cholesky_ref module

bbmm.functions.pivoted_cholesky_ref.pivoted_cholesky_np_gpt(mat: matrix, error_tol=0.001, return_pivots=None, max_iter=15, print_process=False)[source]

mat: numpy matrix of N x N

This is to replicate what is done in GPyTorch verbatim.

in the discussion, error_tol=1e-06, maxiter=50 but I used values in settings.py in linear_operator repository
